Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2009 10:17PM PATTY50 wrote: Telling my mother was the hardest part for me.  As a mother myself, I knew how difficult it would be for her.  She already knew that I had a suspicious lump and that during my mammogram they did a biopsy.  I was supposed to get the results a few days later but was told to come in earlier. When I found out it was cancer I was in shock but mostly upset about having to tell my mother.  I spoke to my sister first to get some advice.  I decided that I should tell my mother in person right away.  When I told her she almost fell over from the shock, but once the initial shock was over, the support she provided was more then I could of asked for.  If I could have waited until I had more information to give her, it would have been better but since she already knew about the biopsy, I had to tell her right away. Also she would have been upset with me for keeping it from her.  I think that it is best that you do tell her in person. I hope it goes well. It will be a relief for you when your family knows and can be there to support you. Patty
